fullProgramDescription: The Department of Mathematics offers a program of study leading to the Bachelor of Science degree. The curriculum provides a foundation in the main areas of mathematics and is designed for students who want a thorough grounding in the field.
shortProgramDescription: MIT's Mathematics B.S. program provides a comprehensive education in the core areas of mathematics, preparing students for graduate study or careers in mathematics and related fields.
classHighlights: Students take 18.01-18.02 (Calculus I-II) or 18.01-18.03 (Calculus I and Honors Calculus I), providing a foundation in calculus.
The program includes 18.100A/18.100B or 18.100P (Real Analysis), 18.701 (Algebra I), and 18.702 (Algebra II), covering advanced algebra and analysis.
Further required courses include 18.06 (Linear Algebra), 18.03 (Differential Equations), and 18.04 (Complex Variables with Applications), ensuring a broad understanding of mathematical concepts.
Electives are chosen from a wide range of mathematics courses, including topics such as number theory, geometry, topology, and differential equations.
The program also allows for study in related fields such as physics, computer science, or engineering, providing a well-rounded education.
learningOutcomes: Demonstrate a thorough understanding of calculus, linear algebra, differential equations, and real and complex analysis.
Apply mathematical principles to solve problems in various mathematical disciplines.
Understand the foundational aspects of mathematics, including algebra, analysis, and geometry.
Prepare for graduate study or careers in mathematics and related fields.
creditRequirements: Total of 180 credits, with at least 8 units of mathematics and 6 units of related fields
additionalInformation: Students must declare the major through the Department of Mathematics. Course selection should be made in consultation with a departmental advisor.
